articles.headline: Can E.U. Shift Migrant Crisis to the Source? In Libya, the Odds Are Long
articles.snippet: A plan to provide money and training to the Libyans to keep migrants there has come under scrutiny for being potentially unworkable and inhumane.
articles.abstract: A plan to provide money and training to the Libyans to keep migrants there has come under scrutiny for being potentially unworkable and inhumane.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ceremony aboard an Italian Navy ship in the port of Valletta, Malta, had all the trappings of a European Union affair. But the “cadets” being awarded certificates on a recent morning were an unusual group — 89 Libyans who the European Union hopes can help solve its migrant problem.
articles.byline: By Gaia Pianigiani and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Trump Aides Try to Reassure Europe, but Many Are Wary
articles.snippet: Key members of Mr. Trump’s cabinet have been scrambling to tell allies that the United States remains a trusted partner.
articles.abstract: Key members of Mr. Trump’s cabinet have been scrambling to tell allies that the United States remains a trusted partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — While President Trump has disrupted assumptions about American foreign policy, members of his cabinet have been scrambling to reassure allies that the United States remains a bedrock of support.

articles.headline: Popular Domestic Programs Face Ax Under First Trump Budget
articles.snippet: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, AmeriCorps and the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities could be eliminated.
articles.abstract: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, AmeriCorps and the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities could be eliminated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House budget office has drafted a hit list of programs that President Trump could eliminate to trim domestic spending, including longstanding conservative targets like the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the Legal Services Corporation, AmeriCorps and the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: The Murky Future of Nuclear Power in the United States
articles.snippet: A nuclear renaissance fizzles as costs soar, green energy makes gains and regulatory pain rises.
articles.abstract: A nuclear renaissance fizzles as costs soar, green energy makes gains and regulatory pain rises.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be America’s nuclear century.

articles.headline: Trump’s ‘Winter White House’: A Peek at the Exclusive Members’ List at Mar-a-Lago
articles.snippet: Demand for membership, and its price, have risen at President Trump’s Florida resort, raising concerns in some quarters about access that only the superwealthy and influential could obtain.
articles.abstract: Demand for membership, and its price, have risen at President Trump’s Florida resort, raising concerns in some quarters about access that only the superwealthy and influential could obtain.
articles.lead_paragraph: On any given weekend, you might catch President Trump’s son-in-law and top Mideast dealmaker, Jared Kushner, by the beachside soft-serve ice cream machine, or his reclusive chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, on the dining patio. If you are lucky, the president himself could stop by your table for a quick chat. But you will have to pay $200,000 for the privilege — and the few available spots are going fast.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Yes, Mr. President, Banks Are Lending
articles.snippet: ‘Nice businesses’ can borrow money, the records show, despite the rules and regulations concerning Wall Street.
articles.abstract: ‘Nice businesses’ can borrow money, the records show, despite the rules and regulations concerning Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the party line: Banks aren’t lending nowadays because the regulatory burden they face is too onerous. And that is hurting the economy and job creation.

articles.headline: Trump, an Outsider Demanding Loyalty, Struggles to Fill Top Posts
articles.snippet: The president is presiding over a government where the upper echelons remain sparsely populated, and not just because of resistance from Democrats.
articles.abstract: The president is presiding over a government where the upper echelons remain sparsely populated, and not just because of resistance from Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Fla. — During President Trump’s transition to power, his team reached out to Elliott Abrams for help building a new administration. Mr. Abrams, a seasoned Republican foreign policy official, sent lists of possible candidates for national security jobs.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Where the Booze Can Kill, and Putin Is Deemed a ‘Good Czar’
articles.snippet: In a remote city’s desperation, where at least 76 people died after drinking a tainted vodka substitute, Russia’s decline writ large.
articles.abstract: In a remote city’s desperation, where at least 76 people died after drinking a tainted vodka substitute, Russia’s decline writ large.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRKUTSK, Russia — The overworked cleaning woman realized that her grown son was not just sleeping off his habitual hangover in the Siberian city of Irkutsk when she discovered — to her horror — that he had quietly gone blind.

articles.headline: Iraq Starts Offensive to Retake Western Mosul From ISIS
articles.snippet: Planes dropped leaflets urging Islamic State fighters to surrender, and new concerns arose about hundreds of thousands of trapped civilians.
articles.abstract: Planes dropped leaflets urging Islamic State fighters to surrender, and new concerns arose about hundreds of thousands of trapped civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Iraq opened the next chapter in its offensive to drive the Islamic State out of Mosul on Sunday, preparing an assault on the western half of the city. Overnight, planes carpeted the ground with leaflets, directly appealing to the group’s fighters to surrender.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Falih Hassan

articles.headline: Texas Oil Fields Rebound From Price Lull, but Jobs Are Left Behind
articles.snippet: The industry is embracing technology, and finding new ways to pare the labor force. But as jobs go away, what of presidential promises to bring them back?
articles.abstract: The industry is embracing technology, and finding new ways to pare the labor force. But as jobs go away, what of presidential promises to bring them back?
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — In the land where oil jobs were once a guaranteed road to security for blue-collar workers, Eustasio Velazquez’s career has been upended by technology.

articles.headline: A Back-Channel Plan for Ukraine and Russia, Courtesy of Trump Associates
articles.snippet: Amid scrutiny of President Trump’s possible ties to Russia, his personal lawyer advances an opposition Ukrainian lawmaker’s sealed plan to the White House.
articles.abstract: Amid scrutiny of President Trump’s possible ties to Russia, his personal lawyer advances an opposition Ukrainian lawmaker’s sealed plan to the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week before Michael T. Flynn resigned as national security adviser, a sealed proposal was hand-delivered to his office, outlining a way for President Trump to lift sanctions against Russia.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Kraft Heinz Withdraws $143 Billion Offer to Merge With Unilever
articles.snippet: Less than 48 hours after Kraft Heinz said it had offered to acquire Unilever, the company, facing a public and possibly costly fight, decided to walk away.
articles.abstract: Less than 48 hours after Kraft Heinz said it had offered to acquire Unilever, the company, facing a public and possibly costly fight, decided to walk away.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday, Kraft Heinz seemed determined to press ahead with a $143 billion takeover bid for Unilever, an ambitious campaign that would have put dozens of the best-known names in consumer households around the world under one roof.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Virtual Reality’s Potential for Magic Gets Real
articles.snippet: The Void, a Utah-based start-up, bets that by making V.R. both social and spontaneous, it can draw throngs and make a mint. Some big names are taking notice.
articles.abstract: The Void, a Utah-based start-up, bets that by making V.R. both social and spontaneous, it can draw throngs and make a mint. Some big names are taking notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINDON, Utah — In an ordinary office complex here, past stacked cartons of Mountain Dew and a throng of hoodie-wearing employees, sits a prototype for an attraction that Hollywood thinks will become the next entertainment craze — an offering that could mint money for its developers, throw a lifeline to struggling shopping malls and, at long last, jump-start sales of virtual reality gear.

articles.headline: Federal Agency Begins Inquiry Into Auto Lenders’ Use of GPS Tracking
articles.snippet: Regulators are investigating whether the devices unfairly violate a borrower’s’ privacy.
articles.abstract: Regulators are investigating whether the devices unfairly violate a borrower’s’ privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: They can figure out when you leave town and see where you parked your car. They can see how many times you went to the grocery store or the health clinic.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Liberals Are Still Angry, but Merrick Garland Has Reached Acceptance
articles.snippet: The thwarted Supreme Court nominee is back at his old job and has not spoken publicly of any frustration, and his friends say they are more aggrieved than he is.
articles.abstract: The thwarted Supreme Court nominee is back at his old job and has not spoken publicly of any frustration, and his friends say they are more aggrieved than he is.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — You might think it would take a toll on a person, being nominated for the Supreme Court and then having to wait around for eight months in a public state of suspended preparation, simultaneously holding out hope and seeing it drift away.

articles.headline: In Trump’s Volleys, Echoes of Alex Jones’s Conspiracy Theories
articles.snippet: President Trump is lending credence to out-there Jonesisms, adding another “pinch-yourself-this-is-happening” element to our national journey into the upside-down.
articles.abstract: President Trump is lending credence to out-there Jonesisms, adding another “pinch-yourself-this-is-happening” element to our national journey into the upside-down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Way back on Friday, President Trump declared that several news organizations — ABC, CBS, CNN, NBC, The New York Times — were “the enemy of the American people.” You know who’s not the enemy, in his book?

articles.headline: Border Wall Would Cleave Tribe, and Its Connection to Ancestral Land
articles.snippet: The Tohono O’odham Nation’s reservation in Arizona extends along 62 miles of the border, with 2,000 members living in Mexico.
articles.abstract: The Tohono O’odham Nation’s reservation in Arizona extends along 62 miles of the border, with 2,000 members living in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN MIGUEL, Ariz. — The phone calls started almost as soon as President Trump signed his executive order, making official his pledge to build a wall to separate the United States from Mexico.
